smell_analysis.justification: No empty diagrams were found; all pages contain relevant model elements.

All use cases are connected to actors either directly or indirectly via «include» relationships (e.g., 'Tuvasta kasutaja' on Page 2 and 'Vaata kõiki ootel...' on Page 3 are included by actor-initiated use cases).
No distinct use cases with synonymous names associated with the same actor were found.
No multiple model elements with the same name were found within the same package.
Data structures appear normalized (e.g., using foreign keys like 'auto_mark_kood' instead of redundant text strings). No obvious denormalization found.
Use case naming is consistent, using the 'Verb + Noun' pattern (e.g., 'Registreeri auto', 'Vaata kõiki autosid').
All states in the state diagram (Page 9) are reachable from the Start node.
All actions in the activity diagram (Page 4) are reachable within the flow.
Visual relationships on class and database diagrams include multiplicity indicators (e.g., '1' and '0..*', or '0..1') where applicable.
No single diagram contains 10 or more central elements. The most populated diagrams (e.g., Page 15) have fewer than 10 central tables/classes.
No single class or table was found with 6 or more visual connection lines on a single diagram page.
Layouts are generally compact and standard; no related elements were found with excessive distance between them (greater than twice the average).
All use cases and activity actions start with active verbs (e.g., 'Vaata', 'Otsi', 'Lõpeta').
No class, table, attribute, or use case names were found to be 3 characters or less.
The class 'Autod' (found on Pages 1, 5, 11, and 12) is named in the plural form, violating the convention that class names should be singular (e.g., 'Auto').
Attribute and column names start with lowercase letters (e.g., 'nimetus', 'isikukood').
Database table names are singular (e.g., 'Auto' on Page 17, 'Klient' on Page 16). The plural 'Autod' was identified as a Class, not a Table.
No type prefixes (like tbl_, cl_, str) were found on element names. Allowed prefixes (PK, FK) are used correctly.
